etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin centrum, from Greek kentron ‘sharp point, stationary point of a pair of compasses’, related to kentein ‘to prick’

notes.text: The construction center around (as opposed to center on, or revolve around) has been denounced as incorrect and illogical since it first appeared in the mid 19th century. Although the phrase is common, it defies geometry by confusing the orbit with the fixed point: the earth revolves around (or its revolution centers on) the sun. A careful writer will use a precise expression, such as centers on, revolves around, concerns, or involves

definitions: the middle point of a circle or sphere, equidistant from every point on the circumference or surface.
a point or part that is equally distant from all sides, ends, or surfaces of something

examples.text: the center of the ceiling
the center of a vast territory

definitions: a political party or group holding moderate opinions

examples.text: a new center party

definitions: (in many sports) the middle player in a line or group

examples.text: many coaches instruct their center to charge viciously on all plays

definitions: the player who is positioned near the basket and is typically tallest on the team

examples.text: only 10 centers averaged more than 10 points per game last year

definitions: a core, such as the filling in a piece of chocolate

examples.text: truffles with liqueur centers

definitions: a pivot or axis of rotation

examples.text: the galactic rotation of the solar system around the galactic center
he flied out to center

definitions: a conical adjustable support for a workpiece in a lathe or similar machine.
the point from which an activity or process is directed, or on which it is focused

examples.text: the city was a center of discontent
two issues at the center of the healthcare debate

definitions: the most important place in the respect specified

examples.text: Geneva was then the center of the international world

definitions: a place or group of buildings where a specified activity is concentrated

examples.text: a center for medical research
a shopping center

notes.text: The construction center around (as opposed to center on, or revolve around) has been denounced as incorrect and illogical since it first appeared in the mid 19th century. Although the phrase is common, it defies geometry by confusing the orbit with the fixed point: the earth revolves around (or its revolution centers on) the sun. A careful writer will use a precise expression, such as centers on, revolves around, concerns, or involves

definitions: occur mainly in or around (a specified place)

examples.text: the mercantile association was centered in northern Germany

definitions: have or cause to have (a specified concern or theme)

examples.text: the case centers around the couple's adopted children
the plot centers on two young men
he is centering his discussion on an analysis of patterns of mortality
to center the needle, turn the knob

definitions: (in soccer, hockey, and other team games) kick, hit, or throw the ball from the side to the middle of the playing area

examples.text: he centered from a difficult position on the left

definitions: pass (the ball) back from the ground to another player to begin a down; snap

examples.text: West Virginia's offense lined up to center the ball

shortDefinitions: pass ball back from ground to another player

definitions: play the central position in (a line of three forwards)

examples.text: Derlago will center Leafs' No. 1 line with Vaive and Clark on wings

shortDefinitions: play central position in forward line
